Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: STEM Real World Applications of Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project builds upon the successful Phase 1 project, STEM Real World Applications Modules. New modules are developed which are closely tied to classroom concepts with mathematics used in industry. The team of investigators includes leaders in the mathematical research and educational communities, and mathematicians with years of industry experience. The overarching goal of this team is to show undergraduate students that strong mathematical skills leads to more employment options and greater chances of success.

The dissemination plan has three main components. The project impacts students and faculty members nationwide through distribution of effective teaching materials. A key part of the dissemination starts with 12 faculty members at 7 additional institutions beta testing the developed modules. After beta-testing, the modules are made available on the project website. Finally presentations about the modules and their effect on student learning are given at conferences, and articles about the modules are submitted to educational and research journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the past 4 years, we have run a “Careers in Mathematics” speaker series at Brigham Young University. This speaker series is designed to motivate and encourage students to study mathematics at the college level and to be aware of and get excited about different career options for students who have good mathematics skills.  During the fall we have 8-9 speakers give a 50-minute presentation to an audience of about 125 students and visitors. Each speaker has a strong background in mathematics and speaks on the importance and value of mathematics in the speaker's particular career and how mathematics can be used in the real world.

The speakers presented on such topics as

  • Data Analytics (Google, PredPol, MITRE, Savvy Sherpa),
  • Tech Consulting (Microsoft, Epic, Fast Enterprises),
  • Mathematical Finance (Goldman Sachs, Capital One, StormHarbour Partners, Bloomberg),
  • Actuarial Science (Hartford, Towers Watson, Beazley)
  • Mathematics and Engineering (Raytheon, Bell Helicopter, Ford Motor Co.),
  • Statistics (Sandia National Labs, Qualtrics)
  • Mathematical Biology/Medicine (Center for Disease Control, Arizona State Univ, Univ. of Utah Medical School)
  • Operations Research (Lawrence Livermore Labs, U.S. Naval Academy)
  • Government (Pentagon, NSA, Homeland Security),
  • Computer-generated Imagery in Movies (Pixar, Freelance)

Also, each year we had a panel consisting of 4-5 students who had done internships the previous summer discussing their internship experiences.

The speaker series has been a tremendous success. Between 80 and 175 students and visitors attended each presentation. On a scale of 1 to 10 (10 being the high), attendees gave the presentations on average rating of 8. Because of the strong interest in the program, it will continue with funding coming from the university
